holidays.name: Eid al-Fitr
holidays.quote: “May Allah accept our fasting and prayers. Eid Mubarak!”
holidays.description: Celebration marking the end of Ramadan, a day of gratitude, prayer, and giving zakat al-fitr.

todos.label: Perform the Eid prayer in congregation
Give zakat al-fitr before the prayer
Celebrate and greet family and friends

facts: Eid al-Fitr is celebrated on the 1st of Shawwal, after the month of Ramadan ends.
Muslims must pay zakat al-fitr (charity) to help those in need before the Eid prayer.
It is a day of joy, thanksgiving, and unity in the Muslim community.
Special foods and sweets are prepared for Eid celebrations.
It is traditional to wear new or best clothes on Eid.

holidays.name: Eid al-Adha
holidays.quote: “Their meat will not reach Allah, nor will their blood, but what reaches Him is piety from you.” (Quran 22:37)
holidays.description: Festival of Sacrifice commemorating Prophet Ibrahim’s devotion and the spirit of submission to Allah.

todos.label: Attend the Eid prayer at the mosque
Remember the story of Prophet Ibrahim’s sacrifice
Distribute meat to family, friends, and the needy

facts: Eid al-Adha is celebrated on the 10th of Dhul Hijjah, coinciding with the Hajj pilgrimage.
It commemorates Prophet Ibrahim’s (Abraham’s) willingness to sacrifice his son as an act of obedience.
Muslims who can afford it offer an animal sacrifice, sharing the meat with the poor.
The day is marked by prayers, community, and acts of charity.
Eid al-Adha lasts for up to three days in many countries.
